figure_1.title: Figure 1:
figure_1.caption: Hypothesized associations between hourly own EDA, hourly partner EDA, hourly own feelings of closeness, hourly own feelings of annoyance, and overall own relationship satisfaction

figure_2.title: Figure 2:
figure_2.caption: Illustration of high linkage in EDA (Panel A), closeness (Panel B), and annoyance (Panel C) for example participating Couple 1 and low linkage in EDA (Panel D), closeness (Panel E), and annoyance (Panel F) for example participating Couple 2 across the day of data collection

figure_3.title: Figure 3:
figure_3.caption: The association between hourly own EDA and hourly partner EDA moderated by hourly own feelings of closeness. Values are plotted at the region of significance (M 2.26 SD: b = .12, p = .05 and M + 2 SD: b = .42, p < .001). Linkage between own and partner EDA is significant at values of own closeness 2.26 SD below the mean and above. EDA = electrodermal activity; µS = microsiemens.

figure_4.title: Figure 4:
figure_4.caption: The association between hourly own EDA and hourly partner EDA moderated by overall own relationship satisfaction. Values are plotted at the region of significance (M 8.13 SD: b = .13, p = .05 and M 2 SD: b = .85, p < .001). Linkage between own and partner EDA is significant at values of own relationship satisfaction 8.13 SD above the mean and below. EDA = electrodermal activity; µS = microsiemens

claims.sentence: Figure 1 presents an overview of the main study questions and hypotheses.

Figure 1:

Open in a new tab
Hypothesized associations between hourly own EDA, hourly partner EDA, hourly own feelings of closeness, hourly own feelings of annoyance, and overall own relationship satisfactionFinally, we examined overall levels of relationship satisfaction as a moderator of linkage processes.
To provide an illustration of high versus low linkage, Figure 2 depicts example data for two participating couples.

Figure 2:

Open in a new tab
Illustration of high linkage in EDA (Panel A), closeness (Panel B), and annoyance (Panel C) for example participating Couple 1 and low linkage in EDA (Panel D), closeness (Panel E), and annoyance (Panel F) for example participating Couple 2 across the day of data collectionHO1: Linkage in EDA in Dating Partners’ Daily Lives
We first tested whether dating partners exhibit linkage in EDA in everyday life by entering level-1 hourly own EDA as a predictor of level-1 hourly partner EDA in a three-level model.
As depicted in Figure 3, participants exhibited heightened linkage in their EDA levels during hours they reported feeling especially close with their romantic partners.

EDA = electrodermal activity; ICC = intraclass correlation coefficient; R2 (S&B) = Snijders & Bosker percent variance explained; Level 2 ICC = .37; Level 3 ICC = .23; R2 [S&B] = 10.52%).Figure 3:

Open in a new tab
The association between hourly own EDA and hourly partner EDA moderated by hourly own feelings of closeness.
See Figure 4 for a depiction of this moderation result.

Bold = significant hypothesized effect; EDA = electrodermal activity; ICC = intraclass correlation coefficient; R2 (S&B) = Snijders & Bosker percent variance explained; Level 2 ICC = .38, Level 3 ICC = .24; R2 (S&B) = 3.00%.Figure 4:

Open in a new tab
The association between hourly own EDA and hourly partner EDA moderated by overall own relationship satisfaction.
Figure 1 presents an overview of the main study questions and hypotheses.
